DOC.HEAD: Surprise, Skepticism Greet Brown Appointment
DOC.TEXT: Police union leaders expressed skepticism and a wait-and-see stand over the appointment of Houston Police Chief Lee Brown as the city's new police commissioner. ``Midtown South is bigger than the whole town of Houston. Our problems are 20 times bigger. Let's see what he can do,'' said Lt. James Gebhardt, head of the Lieutenants Benevolent Association, a union that represents 1,100 lieutenants. Brown, 52, has headed a 4,000-officer department in Houston since 1982, and Gebhardt questioned whether he is prepared to run the 26,000-officer force, the nation's largest. ``The challenges are there. It's whether he can handle a department this big,'' Gebhardt said. Mayor-elect David Dinkins selected Brown on Monday over four other finalists, including the current commissioner, Richard Condon. ``We need the best police commissioner we could find,'' Dinkins told reporters. ``Of all of the finalists, he seemed to be the absolute best in the country.'' Brown will take over Jan. 22 in a city wracked with drug-related crime. The murder rate is at a record level, with crack the prime cause. ``The thing that will hit him immediately is the drug-crime problem,'' said Thomas Reppetto, head of the independent watchdog Citizens Crime Commission and a member of the search committee that interviewed Brown. Brown, who called his appointment a ``once-in-a-lifetime opportunity,'' has served as public safety chief in Houston, Atlanta and Portland, Ore. Small potatoes, some said. ``Atlanta and Houston are different from New York City. I think he's going to find that out very quickly. I think he's got a tough row to hoe,'' said Michael Vecchione, a former department attorney who now sits on the Civilian Complaint Review Board. ``He's an out-of-towner so he'll have to learn the city system,'' said Sgt. Joe Toal, head of the Sergeants Benevolent Association of 3,000 sergeants. ``I guess we're in for a lot of changes.'' Brown is the first commissioner from out of town since Howard Leary of Philadelphia served from 1966-1970. Vecchione said his outsider status wasn't an asset. ``Police officers do not take well to outsiders. It's not going to be easy for him,'' Vecchione said. ``Why did they have to go outside? Does this mean that there is nobody in the NYPD who is qualified?'' asked the Rev. Lawrence Lucas, a black activist who is pastor of the Roman Catholic Church of The Resurrection in Harlem. Condon predicted that Brown's biggest challenge ``is definitely the budget and the fact that we have a tremendous problem with narcotics.'' ``The preliminary estimate is that we are not going to be adding to the police department. If anything, we're going to be losing police officers. I think that's a terrible problem,'' Condon said. Vecchione also said Brown will have a difficult time figuring out New York's police department. ``It will take time until he knows where all the bodies are buried,'' he said.
